comments.commentBody:
From the first paragraph: The president’s senior adviser and confidante on immigration, working with Republicans and whether she’s the Democratic Dick Cheney.

Your hatred blinds you.

The fork in the right hand is interesting. I always chalked it up to cultural differences where the Americans came out on the inefficient side. However, I have lived in 3 European countries and been told it's rude to use a fork "as a shovel" - although of course that is how you use a spoon.

At a party in Amsterdam where it was a buffet style Indonesian meal, I was helping set up and put out knives and forks. Everyone laughed when they realized there were no spoons and asked how I expected people to eat the rice. I replied "with the fork" and was completely mocked. They use forks more as spears and that doesn't work for rice!

Eurocentric, yes. Meaningless and outdated, no.
Head on over to the Santa Fe Steakhouse, on 10th street in McAllen and you'll see those very Eurocentric manners in full display. However, at Diwana in London, Uk, you'll witness all 5 fingers, gleefully using all 5 senses to enjoy an equally fine meal.
Well, if you're doing away with manners, let's all start using our left hands to eat.

I disagree Texas Resident. In addition to discussing manners that are applicable in this century, I think this article also illustrates that manners might be different depending on location. To avoid embarrassment, it's worth learning and adopting customs and manners of any country you plan to visit. You may eat an Indian meal with your hands when in India and with a fork in the U.S. I would enjoy the dish no matter what! Now I'm hungry...

The enjoyment of food involves all the senses, including touch. The manners listed in the article are eurocentric, outdated and many are outright meaningless.
I would love to eat my Indian dishes, be it Chapattis with curry or Sambar with rice, with the involvement of all of my right hand fingers, even if I avoid licking them when in a group setting! There is no other way.
Perhaps in some quarters in LA, no one cares, but it is far better than ending up spooning it and dripping the soup on the tablecloth or ones lap.

Nick, as a consumer of considerable quantities of animal protein I, too, share that feeling of being "conflicted. " Nevertheless, I think it's splitting hairs to protest the horrific deaths of so many factory farm animals that have likely been subjected to horrific conditions for all or most of their poultry existence.

While personally non-religious and never having subscribed to any sectarian dietary observances, I do favor kosher and halal butchering techniques as not only more humane means of depriving an animal of its life -- Hopefully your readers won't find a concept of humane killing too overtly oxymoronic -- but, in terms of flavor, of producing meat that can't be beat.

Unless you were in the crowd that day, you have no idea what actually went on. You might want to read accounts of what happened by real live journalists. You diminish the term "hate crime" when you throw it around like you've done,
Buying a ticket allows one to boo. Why would an apology be required? It certainly appears that Venus tanked. Who cares. They are great tennis players.

I have to run to defend Serena in this case. No, you haven't been watching much of Serena after matches lately. She has become the soul of good sportsmanship in praising her opponent. A lot better than in the earlier years. Also, that official didn't run off the court. Where did you come up with that one?
Let's see your ticket stub. Your story sounds like baloney.
Venus bowed out of a match with Serena 5 minutes before they were to come on court. The next day the crowd booed them vociferously. "Mania of white racism?" Give it a rest.
I haven't heard either of the sisters claim to have heard any racial epithets that day in Indian Wells. Have you? Has anyone?
So, Mary, do you suffer from chronic pain? Have they cut off your medication yet?

It has become clear that the right to life in this context means the requirement to suffer imposed by a religion in violation of the First Amendment. Like the anti-choice, pro-embryo folks they want to interfere with personal or medical choices. It's a shame that the religious can't let "free will." govern our choices as intended

"nose-stickers-into-other-people's-business"

That is what it all comes down to isn't it? People whose need to boss other people around and stick their noses in where they have no business and the high they get from having control over others knows no bounds. But let anyone try to stop them from molesting children and suddenly it is no ones business but the church!

It really is just about control freaks meddling in everyone's business while ignoring their own.

The Catholic church hieirarchy in Montana plus some fundamentalists -- not all -- in Montana have been "doing their damndest" to spell out, to pass a bill in the now-meeting state legislature, with 10-year prison terms, for MDs who help terminally ill people die without being totally wiped out by too much suffering. Just this past week, it passed second reading in the House, but apparerently died on third reading -- Hallelujah!

They'll keep on trying. I at 87 with health problems may end up having to do away with myself sooner than would be necessary if the right-to-lifers -- sometimes known as nose-stickers-into-other-people's-business manage to succeed in the near future.

I've never read any comments from fans who claimed to have heard racial epithets directed at Venus or Richard Williams that day in Indian Wells. Further, do really want to put a bunch of disgruntled fan booing in the same universe with real racial problems that have occurred of late?

Perhaps, but not booed for hours and throughout the entirety of the match, and it's exarcerbated since tennis is a one-person sport not team.  Also, there is really basic etiquette of not booing double faults while serving; and not booing when the winner won the match;  the crowd in 2001 did all this. It was such a grievous breach of etiquette, at least in tennis.
However, getting booed (which they richly deserved) needn't have a racially biased component. Got it?
Seems to me they value the second amendment more than the ten commandments.
The Williams sister are treated like royalty everywhere they go. Maybe they are tired of all the adulation.
Prove that there were racial slurs scream at any of the Williams family.
Serena is a class act. She has shown time again that she can rise against any adversity and remain a champion in every sense of the word.

Roy - There's another problem besides the cruelty: meat is fundamentally unsustainable. The industry receives massive govt subsidies in the form of corn subsidies, grazing permits (on public land!), etc., so it's economically unsustainable. And it massively pollutes and contributes to climate change so it's environmentally unsustainable. The movie Cowspiracy, www.cowspiracy.com, gives a great overview.

Unfortunately, the most sustainable farms are the cruelest - the ones like Mr. Kristof describes, where the most animals are crammed into the smallest spaces with the least care.

The more you look into the realities of meat, dairy, and egg production, the clearer it becomes that the only truly ethical choice is to go vegan.

In 2001 Semifinals match, Serena was set to play against Venus. The crowds were already in the stadium, and minutes later they were informed Venus pulled out due to injury. There were rumors that the sisters father orchestrated this, so that the sisters wouldn't have to play one another; a rumor exarcerbated by magazine rumors, and other jealous tennis players. The crowd was mightily unhappy.

The next day, Serena is into the finals with Kim Clijsters. When she, Venus, and father entered the stadium, they were booed viciously. The boo continued throughout the match for hours; with the crowds cheering for Serena's errors, her double faults, and booing her when she won the match. Her Father claimed racial epithets were thrown against him; some say unfounded, but Billie Jean King and other attendants confirmed this indeed happened.

Serena and Venus then boycotted the tournament since that day in 2001. This tournament is not a small one. This is the largest tournament besides the 4 Grandslams, often called the 5th Grand Slam, a mandatory event. The sisters continued to boycott, also bcs of fear of returning. Serena was also 19 at that time, as a teenager at the beginning of her career, couldn't understand why this happened.

14 years, 18 grand slam wins later, and at the twilight of her career, Serena, at age 34, decided she wanted to rewrite this horrible chapter by returning to Indian wells, forgiving the tournament, and let go all of her feelings and move on.

Thanks you J. V. for the suggestion to go to Youtube and watch what happened rather than anyone reporting what they "thought" happened.

Here is a link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YEIeZczHa2Q

You be the judge of how the crowd acted and what possibly was said. The video is 30 minutes long but in the first 5 minutes you get an idea of what Serena faced. It is all there for anyone to see and hear.

Now... can we please MOVE ON Serena has, Indian Wells has, and so should we.

Can't wait for "Indian Wells," the movie.

NOT!

There are plenty of churchgoing, God-fearing poor, and their traditional morality has not been a pathway to success for many of them. The states with the strongest traditional morality and the weakest safety net are the poorest, and lure industry with the promise of cheap, docile, nonunion labor.

We know how to do something about income inequality, and we can try to lessen it without stalling or shrinking the economy. Whether this is possible or not depends on the economic theory used, but we could try. If we wanted to reimpose segregation in parts of the country, we could do it and it would be ugly, sort of like what the Nazis did to Germany.

Imposing traditional morality would take the same sort of effort. Decent people would not let their kids associate with illegitimate children, and women who became pregnant outside of wedlock would be objects of scorn and experience job discrimination. Young women who did not protect their virginity by avoiding parties or going out after dark alone or dressing modestly would be blamed for anything that happened. Those who did not reinforce the right moral lessons would find themselves in trouble. Group pressure would once more stifle individual freedom.

If sermons could restore traditional morality, it would have happened already. If we put it back, it would have the same problems that motivated most of us to turn away from its hypocrisy, fixed roles to play, and many injustices for women and those on the bottom.

Nick, thanks for your articles about animal suffering. I do not believe most people really care about it or they have never considered it. These animals feel pain exactly the same way that you and I do. I buy beef and chicken at Whole Foods because they claim that the animals are raised and slaughtered humanely, but I don't know for sure. It may be hypocritical, but I believe a quick, painless death for an animal is ethical way to get protein. In terms of evolution, humans could not have grown the brains we have if we did not consume animal protein - the brain just uses too much energy. Nowadays of course, there are alternatives and it is much easier to obtain food.
